title: How to Find the Third Angle of a Triangle

steps.title: Add up the two known angle measurements.
steps.content: Add up the two known angle measurements. All you have to know is that all of the angles in a triangle always add up to 180°. This is true 100% of the time. So, if you know two of the three measurements of the triangle, then you're only missing one piece of the puzzle. The first thing you can do is add up the angle measurements you know. In this example, the two angle measurements you know are 80° and 65°. Add them up (80° + 65°) to get 145°. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Subtract this number from 180°.
steps.content: Subtract this number from 180°. The angles in a triangle add up to 180°. Therefore, the remaining angle must make a sum up the angles up to 180°. In this example, 180° - 145° = 35°. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Write down your answer.
steps.content: Write down your answer. You now know that the third angle measures 35°. If you're doubting yourself, just check your work. The three angles should add up to 180° for the triangle to exist. 80° + 65° + 35° = 180°. You're all done. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Write down the problem.
steps.content: Write down the problem. Sometimes, instead being lucky enough to know the measurements of two of the angles of a triangle, you'll only be given a few variables, or some variables and an angle measurement. Let's say you're working with this problem: Find the measurements of angle "x" of the triangle whose measurements are "x," "2x," and 24. First, just write it down. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Add up all of the measurements.
steps.content: Add up all of the measurements. It's the same principle that you would follow if you did know the measurements of the two angles. Simply add up the measurements of the angles, combining the variables. So, x + 2x + 24° = 3x + 24°. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Subtract the measurements from 180°.
steps.content: Subtract the measurements from 180°. Now, subtract these measurements from 180° to get closer to solving the problem. Make sure you set the equation equal to 0. Here's what it would look like: 180° - (3x + 24°) = 0 180° - 3x - 24° = 0 156° - 3x = 0

steps.title: Solve for x.
steps.content: Solve for x. Now, just put the variables on one side of the equation and the numbers on the other side. You'll get 156° = 3x. Now, divide both sides of the equation by 3 to get x = 52°. This means that the measurement of the third angle of the triangle is 52°. The other angle, 2x, is 2 x 52°, or 104°. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Check your work.
steps.content: Check your work. If you want to make sure that this is a valid triangle, just add up the three angle measurements to make sure that they add up to 180°. That's 52° + 104° + 24° = 180°. You're all done.

steps.title: Find the third angle of an isosceles triangle.
steps.content: Find the third angle of an isosceles triangle. Isosceles triangles have two equal sides and two equal angles. The equal sides are marked by one hash mark on each of them, indicating that the angles across from each side are equal. If you know the angle measurement of one equal angle of an isosceles triangle, then you'll know the measurement of the other equal angle. Here's how to find it: [7] X Research source If one of the equal angles is 40°, then you'll know that the other angle is also 40°. You can find the third side, if needed, by subtracting 40° + 40° (which is 80°) from 180°. 180° - 80° = 100°, which is the measurement of the remaining angle.

steps.title: Find the third angle of an equilateral triangle.
steps.content: Find the third angle of an equilateral triangle. An equilateral triangle has all equal sides and all equal angles. It will typically be marked by two hash marks in the middle of each of its sides. This means that the angle measurement of any angle in an equilateral triangle is 60°. Check your work. 60° + 60° + 60° = 180°. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Find the third angle of a right triangle.
steps.content: Find the third angle of a right triangle. Let's say you know you have a right triangle, with one of the other angles being 30°. If it's a right triangle, then you know that one of the angles measures exactly 90°. The same principles apply. All you have to do is add up the measurements of the sides you know (30° + 90° = 120°) and subtract that number from 180°. So, 180° - 120° = 60°. The measurement of that third angle is 60°. [9] X Research source
